title: Quiz 2: Infection & Oncology
description: Evaluate your knowledge of anti-infective agents (antibiotics, antifungals, antivirals) and antineoplastic drugs, focusing on classifications, side effects, and nursing care (Units 4-7).

questions.question: Match the antibiotic class with its specific mechanism of action or key characteristic:

pairs.right: Inhibits cell wall synthesis; effective against rapidly dividing organisms
Inhibits protein synthesis; deposits in calcifying teeth
Structurally related to PABA; inhibits folic acid synthesis
Inhibits protein synthesis; known for ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity

questions.explanation: Penicillins attack cell walls. Tetracyclines bind to calcium. Sulfonamides are antimetabolites (folic acid). Aminoglycosides are potent protein synthesis inhibitors with specific toxicities.
questions.hint: Think about which one affects bones/teeth vs. kidneys/ears.

questions.question: A patient is prescribed Tetracycline. Which dietary instruction is most important for the nurse to provide?

options.text: Take with a glass of milk to prevent gastric irritation.
Take with fruit juice to enhance absorption.
Avoid milk, antacids, or iron preparations near the time of administration.
Eat a high-fat meal immediately before taking the medication.

questions.explanation: Calcium (milk), aluminum/magnesium (antacids), and iron form insoluble precipitates with Tetracycline in the GI tract, preventing absorption.
questions.hint: Certain minerals bind to this drug and stop it from working.

questions.question: Which of the following are major toxic effects associated with Aminoglycosides (e.g., Gentamicin)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Aminoglycosides are powerful antibiotics but carry risks of ear damage (ototoxicity), kidney damage (nephrotoxicity), and neurotoxicity. Teeth discoloration is Tetracycline; Red-Man is Vancomycin.
questions.hint: Think about the ears and the kidneys.

questions.question: Third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., Ceftriaxone) have less activity against gram-negative organisms but enter the CSF better than first-generation cephalosporins.
questions.explanation: False. Third-generation cephalosporins have MORE activity against gram-negative organisms and enter the CSF (inflamed meninges) readily compared to 1st and 2nd generations.
questions.hint: Review the progression from 1st to 3rd generation.

questions.question: The severe reaction characterized by rhinitis, conjunctivitis, fever, stomatitis, and rash, often associated with Sulfonamides, is known as ___BLANK___ syndrome.
questions.explanation: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe hypersensitivity reaction affecting the skin and mucous membranes, a potential side effect of Sulfonamides.
questions.hint: Named after two people, hyphenated.

questions.question: A patient receiving Vancomycin IV develops chills, fever, and erythema of the neck and back. What is this reaction called, and what is the likely cause?
questions.explanation: Red-Neck (or Red Man) syndrome involves flushing/erythema of the neck/back caused by histamine release due to rapid IV administration of Vancomycin.
questions.hint: The name describes the physical appearance of the patient's upper body.

questions.question: Review the Antineoplastic Safety Table. Which nursing action violates safety protocols for handling chemotherapy?

richContent.content:
Chemotherapy Safety Protocols

  • Prepare in designated area away from cooling/heating vents
  • Wear non-permeable surgical gown with knit cuffs
  • Use latex gloves to protect skin
  • Use piggyback setup with electronic pump
  • Avoid dorsum of hand or wrist for infusion sites

options.text: Washing hands before and after preparation.
Using a new IV site rather than a previously used one.
Starting the infusion with an unmedicated solution first.

questions.explanation: Antineoplastic agents are toxic. They should be prepared by trained personnel, and specifically NOT by pregnant personnel due to teratogenic risks.
questions.hint: Who should strictly avoid exposure to cytotoxic drugs?

questions.question: Which of the following are indications for the use of Metronidazole (Flagyl)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Metronidazole is effective against protozoa (Trichomonas, Ameba) and anaerobic bacteria. It is not an antifungal or antiviral.
questions.hint: Think parasites and anaerobes.

questions.question: What is the specific antidote for a patient experiencing bleeding due to Heparin overdose?
questions.explanation: Protamine Sulfate is the specific antidote that neutralizes the anticoagulant activity of Heparin.
questions.hint: Starts with 'P'.

questions.question: Which antibiotic is historically known to cause 'Gray Baby Syndrome' in neonates due to their inability to metabolize the drug?
questions.explanation: Chloramphenicol can cause Gray Baby Syndrome (pallid cyanosis, vasomotor collapse) in infants because their immature livers cannot conjugate the drug.
questions.hint: This drug is also associated with aplastic anemia.

questions.question: Nystatin is primarily used to treat infections caused by the organism ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Nystatin is an antifungal specific for Candida infections (e.g., oral thrush, vaginal candidiasis).
questions.hint: Also known as yeast or moniliasis.

questions.question: A patient taking Penicillin G should NOT have the medication mixed in the same IV syringe/solution with which drug due to inactivation?
questions.explanation: Penicillins can physically/chemically inactivate Aminoglycosides (like Gentamicin) if mixed in the same container. They must be administered separately.
questions.hint: Interaction between two major antibiotic classes.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for administering an oral Nystatin suspension for oral thrush:

items.text: Swish/hold in mouth as long as possible

questions.explanation: Nystatin suspension works by contact. It must be shaken, then held in the mouth to coat the lesions before swallowing.
questions.hint: Contact time with the fungus is crucial.

questions.question: Which nursing intervention is appropriate for a patient receiving high-dose Methotrexate?

options.text: Monitoring for signs of bone marrow depression.

questions.explanation: Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that can cause severe bone marrow depression (leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia). Monitoring blood counts is critical.
questions.hint: Chemotherapy targets rapidly dividing cells.

questions.question: Acyclovir (Zovirax) cures herpes viral infections by killing the virus completely.
questions.explanation: False. Acyclovir interferes with viral DNA replication. It treats active infections and reduces duration/severity but does not cure or eradicate the latent virus.
questions.hint: Think about the nature of viral infections.

questions.question: Which drug is used for the treatment of Rickettsial infections (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever) and is considered the drug of choice?
questions.explanation: Tetracyclines are the drugs of choice for Rickettsial infections, Mycoplasma, and Chlamydia.
questions.hint: This drug has a broad spectrum but specific contraindications for children.

questions.question: Match the specific drug to its classification:
questions.explanation: Mebendazole treats worms; Amantadine treats Flu A/Parkinson's; Miconazole treats fungi; Tamoxifen is used for breast cancer.
questions.hint: Look at the suffixes or common uses.

questions.question: A client is prescribed Ciprofloxacin (a Quinolone). What instruction should be emphasized to prevent crystalluria?
questions.explanation: Patients taking Ciprofloxacin should drink increased fluids to keep urine acidic and minimize the risk of crystalluria (crystals forming in urine).
questions.hint: The kidneys need water to flush this drug out safely.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of 'Superinfection' that may occur during long-term antibiotic therapy? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Superinfection occurs when normal flora is eradicated, allowing opportunistic organisms (fungi, resistant bacteria) to overgrow, causing thrush, vaginitis, or colitis.
questions.hint: Think about what happens when 'good bacteria' are killed off.

questions.question: What is the term for a drug that halts the growth/multiplication of bacteria but relies on the host's immune system to kill them?
questions.explanation: Bacteriostatic drugs stop multiplication (static), whereas bactericidal drugs kill the organisms.
questions.hint: Static means standing still.
